Review Text: This is a popular location for bird watchers. There lots of migratory birds during the season including flamingos. Beaches also.
A very historic place and is said to be the closest place to India. The place seems to be modernising too soon and could harm the flamingos that normally migrate here with seasonal changes.
It has very peaceful environment. Also this place does miracles. You can enjoy the nature there with a lot of space trees birds etc

The tranquility of this place is being spoiled by major road development and the placement of up to eighty wind turbines.  The salt flats where flamingo migrate to are next to a set of road works and now the only way to see flamingo is to get up at 0500 before the traffic starts The beaches are mostly in use for fishing so are not nice or clean enough to relax and enjoy The area also has a major problem with drug trafficking and drug taking. We found a nice beach area only to be joined by a group of locals doing cocaine On the positive side we enjoyed a couple of walks beside the salterns and saw lots of painted storks and pelicans
There is a lot of history and interesting places to visit, the Doric, where the world acclaimed fresh water pearls were found. Fort at Arippu nearby and a larger Fort at Mannar

Review Title: Not a popular tourist spot, but there’s plenty to see
Review Text: You have many places to visit at Mannar island although many simply ignore this place due to the extreme hot weather and less facilities. But it’s a must visit at least once. Mannar is famous for flamingoes in the migratory season. You can see them beside the road connecting Mannar and main island. Some of the major attractions are Mannar fort, thaleimannar pier and light house, thaleimannar beach, adam’s bridge, Keeri beach. The Adam’s bridge is a must visit from all of this. Specially visit in evenings, the sunset view would be amazing. If you can get navy permission they’ll take you on a boat ride towards the first island of town he adams bridge. On the way to Mannar you can visit Doric bungalow, arippu fort, Madhu church and thanthrimale temple.

Review Title: Mannar, a Place Like No Other in Sri Lanka!
Review Text: It's like stepping back to the Eighties! No fast food, just one supermarket, no traffic lights and NO TRAFFIC, but you enter a land where donkeys roam freely, Baobob trees grow amidst the thorny shrub, desolate white sandy landscape stretches for miles. Near empty roads, lush Palmyra trees and birds, hundreds and hundreds of them everywhere.  If you go off the beaten track, there's a stretch of beach which is completely isolated in parts except for a tiny fishing village or two. The silence only punctuated by bird calls is therapeutic, to say the least. I am of couse referring to Mannar Island, rather than Mannar on mainland. The only tiny disappointment was the Mannar Fort but the huge Baobob tree, supposedly over 800years old and, 22.8 metres in circumference, made up for it. The drive to Talaimannar Pier is absolutely beautiful,  hardly a single vehicle passes by. As if all this is not enough, a Donkey Clinic!!, over 30 donkeys live there and one can feed and pet them. We're definitely going back for the birding season, which is from November to around March I believe.

Review Title: An interesting island offering new experiences and discovering more to explore...
Review Text: beyond the dry arid landscape Mannar Island has more and more to offer. From observing the migratory flamingoes that escape the harsh winter to Kite surfing at Ayu, to an exploration of the old dutch fort Mannar is still raw and untouched and unspoiled by mass tourism.
A good place and a admiring place with see more sea side view with more old port and near railway station too

Went there as it was the only town in Sri Lanka that I had not visited. Not a great deal to see. However, there are some superb sea bathing spots close to Thallaimannar pier. Ask the Naval personnel on duty and they will guide you. The sea was the warmest it has ever been (in my memory) and the sun set is a photographers dream.

This is an unfeveloped region of Sri Lanka but really worth going there if you're interested in birds. Nov-Mar is the best time to see resident birds but also many migrants. There are also quite a lot of wild donkeys - the only area where see these lovely animals - which were apparently introduced by Arab traders but not used by the locals now.

Mannar has a manner, mythology and meaning, all its own. Located in the North West of Sri Lanka, the island is now connected to the mainland by way of causeways, creating easy access to this strange little place, full of donkeys, people and peculiar mannerisms. Mannar incidentally is the closest point to India and on a clear day, when the tide is low you can almost see our neighbours above us. Mythic tales tell of an invisible bride binding the 2 nations together, woven by jewels left like a Hansel and Gretel narrative by Sita when she was taken by King Ravana to Lanka. But this is 21st century Mannar and mythology has become a modern thing; multiple faiths and ethnicities reside here – as do multiple species of animals. You might find stray dogs meandering the streets elsewhere in Sri Lanka, but in Mannar, donkeys rule the streets. Old, abandoned houses named in honour of women with English names sit on lonely streets where two wheelers and four-legged ones occupy rush hour and colonial forts sit abandoned on the edge of little towns. Check out a travelzine called The Fowler for more interesting insights about the North!

Enough to fill a couple of days starting from the Fort and working out to Talaimannar.  Baobab old tree is fascinating if a bit grotesque.  The pier at Ta.. is a sad story considering how important it was many years ago.  We even came from India though here with our Land Rover many years back.
Lovely place to spend the day with lots of bird watching. We loved the natural beauty of the place and not too many tourists.
The road could be better. We did not mind it as we were eager to explore Mannar. We were not disappointed. Loved It.

This island connected to the Mannar mainland by a causeway is actually Thalaimannar. It's 30 km long and a few kilometres wide - in some places more than 10 km. It's part of the hot Northern province of Sri Lanka more than 300km away from the capital city of Colombo. It's human settlements have a colonial origin comprising Dutch Fort, numerous churches. The island is populated by Tamil Christians and Muslims using Tamil as the widely spoken language. The main source of income for the people here is fishing. However, tourism is beginning to play a major role, too. There's a saltern on the western side of the city. The city is dead on Sundays with most businesses closed to the public. Only a few convenience stores and restaurants are open on Sundays including the much talked about Choice restaurant. The island doesn’t still have many places for tourists to stay. There are only a couple of luxury accommodations in the island. There are a few comfortable budget accommodations, in addition. The main attraction of the island is as a birding site. During the migratory season November to March. Around 1000 Flamingos visit the island to feed on the crustaceans found in abundance in the saltern and other areas with shallow salty water pools. In January to early February beautiful pink color developing in primary feathers of Flamingos is a treat to the eyes of the birders - both local and foreign. Large amounts of Copper in the Crustaceans they feed on are responsible for this color. You must watch them flying to appreciate the true beauty! But, please don't try to chase them so that they fly for you to see this magical display. If you wait long enough at a safe distance away they will eventually fly above you, especially if you are lucky! If they do you should certainly try your luck in whatever way you like for the day!  In addition to the Flamingos there are numerous other birds to watch, especially several species of Ducks, Glossy ibis, Western reef heron etc. You got to be in field before the sunrise to witness the birds in their true glory. You must make it a point to visit Thalaimannar area as well for the scintillating ride and the sights including the old pier, fishing harbour with an abundance of terns and gulls in addition to egrets and birds of prey fighting for fish thrown away by the fishermen. The other attractions of the island include the giant Baobab tree near the city,  the Dutch Fort,  Adam's bridge etc. Wankalai sanctuary is only a few kilometres from the island on the main land which is home to a large population of migratory water birds. Driving on your own in this sparsely populated island is a delight. You can make the best use of your stay if you can spare at least three days here. You can reach the island by car, bus or train. Train and bus rides can be harder during hotter months as air conditioning is not commonplace in public transport to this part of the country. If you have a genuine 4 WD vehicle it's possible to take a memorable drive to Mannar from Puttalam, through the Wilpattu jungle during certain times of the year when the gravel road is not flooded.

My wife and I visited Mannar on 25th and 26th December 2018 and again on 12th & 13th January 2019, with the main objective of watching the migratory Flamingos.  We were unfortunate during our first visit as the Flamingos kept far out in the sea near the causeway.  We were lucky during the second visit!! They were there in their hundreds at the Mannar Salterns.  They arrived early morning around 0600 and kept feeding in the semi-saline waters while making their typical clucking noise.  It was a beautiful sight to see them coming on to land with the sun shining on them against the blue sky.  There were quite a crowd gathered there to witness this scene that happens only during the migratory season from about December to February each year.  We were advised to wear dull coloured clothing and not move too close to the group of birds to avoid scaring them away.  There were bird-watchers with binoculars and photographers with long-lens cameras feasting their eyes on the flock of beautiful pinkish birds. In addition to the Flamingos we also visited the Pesalai, a fishing beach where there were many birds such as gulls, terns, and brahimini kites.  We also visited Thiruketheeswaran temple and the famed Baobab tree.  In the evenings we went around looking for other migratory birds.  There are many places of interest around this little islet, Mannar, that we had visited in our previous annual visits. The main road from Mannar to Talaimannar is not in very good state rutted with potholes.  There were not many tourists too other than those who came to see the birds.  It is not a very busy place.  The seafood in many a local eating houses were spicy and tasty. We will go there again next year!!

The island has a long and varied history which would be nice to fully understand.  The island is not set up for tourists and you have to work for information.  Overall the 'not touristy' way of this place suited us.

This is a good place for a silent getaway. However better to book a reputed place for meals and accommodation because I did not see many eateries/lodgings except the one I stayed. I spent the time in Talaiannar (Vayu resort). They provide bicycles free and you can bird watch too. Also yo may kite surf (paid activity) which is really exciting.

Because this island was excellent for natural pearls many people came to trade with, greeks, roman, arabs and also was the shorter way to cruise india. But now is a lazy town and island with some beaches of blue water in the season and projects of big resorts.

One of the best place in sri lanka for bird watching specially during migratory bird season (December - January). Lot of birds can be seen by the sides of south cost road, Punarin road and thaleimannar road.

There are many places to visitt Mannar Island.Mannar fort, Biobab tree, Arippu fort, Doric bunglow, Vankalai sanctuary ,Widatalthivu Sanctuary ,Mathota Temple ,Thiruketheeswaram kovil, Talaimannar pier ,Adam's bridge,Light house, Giant's tank,Suspension bridge ,Giant's tank sanctuary and many more.
This is good to spend a day.The accommodation is limited so have to early .The  old fort  Babok tree and the beach main attraction. The sea food is excellent.

Though nothing much to see in Mannar it was a good drive from Colombo since the roads are good. Madu Church, Thirukkeswaram Load Shiva Temple, Mannar Dutch fort, Biobab tree, and Thalimannar Pier are few attactions around Mannar. Plenty on donkeys on the road. They said it’s a place to see Flamingos but we couldn’t see since it was not the season. Maximum one day is ok.
Beat clean view . Nice view and relaxing environment. Place to visit and relaxing walk along the sea

We drove from Jaffna,  the journey out and the entry into Mannar is pretty . Mannar town itself is featureless. For the tourist lacks even the bare necessities - food, toilets etc . Development upside is when trading  and travel to/from India recommences. In the interim better bang for spend in Jaffna and surrounds . Probably there are experiences if you want to find a hamlet and pretend that you are a villager for a period off the grid!
You need to visit to this peer which is in Mannar Island. The peer now very damaged & not allowed to go beyond this point.

The island can be travelled by bicycle or by scooter. We went all the way to Talaimannar to see the lighthouse and afterwards we watched the sunset at Keeri beach (bit disappointed by the garbage there). A lot of donkeys on this island, hence the nickname of the citizens. Not a lot of tourists so a totally different vibe.
Mannar - no words. Simple, calm, peace, ... and lot of donkeys :) Fishermen's cottages, Indian ocean, shells. Only few accomodation, but enough.
Please visit this place late evening as the sun is very strong until late evening.  The light house looks so magnificent and you can look out to the sea when you stand next to it.

I am sure that a visit to Mannar in sunny weather would be a very different experience.  However we travelled out of season, the skies were gray with occasional rain, and generally it was a bit miserable.  There didn't seem to be very much to do but perhaps a bit more research would have brought better results.  But if you have to choose then I would say Jaffna every time.

The Mannar area is mainly aimed at bird watching. If you arrive at your accommodation early then take a drive out to the lighthouse and see the jetty at Adams Bridge which is the closest part of the coast to India. Its nothing special but most people do this.
Amazing place nice people here in Shri Lanka. When you see this palace you can check India is too close. without any glass instrument, you can check  India.

History of Sri Lanka and India where the Ramasetu bridge is. there are lot of islets supposed to have been remanants of a bridge built by Rama king of India when he came to rescue his wife Seeta. Good for seafood and very few places where you have comfortable accommodation therefore you need to book in advance
We stayed in mannar for 2 days but we found that there was not a lot to see. One day is enough to visit the whole island.

The drive to Mannar from the main island of Sri Lanka is amazing! The ocean on both sides and the blue skies above it is almost like a postcard! The first attraction you will spot when you get into Mannar is the dutch fort. Definitely worth a visit! Most of the fort is intact and you can walk around and take some photos of the ocean from up there. Further down the road, you can visit the Baobob tree which is the tree with the largest bark in Sri Lanka. The tree is not native to Sri Lanka so its a mystery as to how it actually got there! Rumor has it that Arabian sailors brought it over ;) From Mannar town, you can drive up to Talaimannar which is home to the naval base and Talaimannar pier. The pier was used to board ships which go to India back in the day. Sadly, the ferry service is no longer active. On the drive to Talaimannar you pass beautiful scenery on both sides of the road. If you get down and walk off the road you will see that the white sand is covered by beautiful little shells! The area is aptly named the Shell coast cos of this. Right along the drive you will see heaps of Donkeys strolling along the sides of the roads which is quite and unusual sight for Sri Lanka :) The island has its own little post office which is the furthest most post office towards the west of the island. We bought some post cards and sent it across to ourselves from there as a fun little souvenir :) When back in town, make sure to visit Choice restaurant which is a small cheap food shop. Amazing fried rice and Biriyani available for Lunch and dinner. 5 of us had food and drinks, and the bill came to only LKR 1,500.00 Mannar island is definitely a must see for all locals and foreigners :) Just make sure to hire or drive your own vehicle since there is a lot of driving around to do :)

Wonderful. Unbelievable. Mannar is a hidden gem in Sri Lanka. Suggest travellers to read the book "Discover Mannar" by Mr.Amrith Gnanam before visiting Mannar. Ideal for birding, photography and relaxing.

Mannar is an Island off the mainland Sri Lanka. However district of Mannar covers parts the mainland. Key sites you may be interested include 1. Silavaturai, Arippu, Coastal wetlands and archaeological sites 2. Vankalai Bird Sanctuary and beach 3. Silavaturai, Aripput and Vankalai coral reefs, undiscovered live corals 4. Talaimannar Pier, Adam Bridge, several archeological sites and Pesalai fishery harbour 5. Mannar Port and Mantai port 6. Madhu Church, religious sites 7. Vidattaltivu lagoon and extensive coastal habitat with mangroves Climate & Geography Avg Temperature December - Feb 26C April - June  above 29C (Avoid going during this time) Rest of the year - 28C History Talaimannar is 18 miles away from india and during good times was a centre of trade and sea routes. Baobab tress and donkeys are a reminder of this even to this date, that traders from Arabia frequented this place. The fact that dutch chose to build a fort also goes to prove its bygone hub status. Kuweni, as the legend has it is from Thambapanni which is in Mannar district of Wilpattu reserve though not in the island. Adam's bridge or Hanuman's bridge also is there though there are no formal tours. Modi went to Talai Mannar to initiate a train service back in 2015 is still showing its strategic value to be connecting point to the Asian Railway Network. Wild Life Mannar sees migratory birds during seasons, especially flamingoes. Wild donkeys and poneys too can be seen. Coral reafs are also available. Again no formal tours In past, mannar was famous for natural pearls; though it is not commercially done now at large scale. Go to keeri beach Economy Economy is mainly based on fishing and agriculture. Food If you are in mannar, eat sea food. Prawns and cuttle fish are out of the world, but you need to get them fresh and cook. Only one proper resturant imo (Palmyrah). THough small shops also serve tasty curry. I am told cargills has opened in mannar town; please check. If not, take plenty of water bottles. Travel No 95 petrol is available in the island, Last station apparently is in Madu. Use TukTuk but discuss the rates prior to travelling. If difficult get help of a resident. THere are air conditioned buses between mannar and colombo. Leaves Mannar opposite Sri Lanka telecom.

We rented two bycicles to explore the island. There are no real special things to see but its just a wonderful way to get to know mannar and its people. Everyone we met was really nice and helpful. There are also many small shops on the way where you can buy drinks and snacks. Be prepaired for the sun. There are not many shady places. To deive from mannar to the lighthouse it takes something about 3 hours (slowly driving and stops included). Was hot and exhausting but definitely worth it!
The sea is gorgeous, not an over crowded town, so peaceful and beautiful. Now there are few hotels.  You can drive to Talaimannar where the sea is also so gorgeous.  Real out of the ordinary place.
Lot of birds. Once there was a very to India. You can visit Adam's Bridge. The only place you can find the Baobab Tree in Sri Lanka. A lot of wild donkeys. Old Portuguese/Dutch fort.

Even though this listing is say Manna Island, the best place to visit here is Talaimanna Pier. This is a very old pier, earlier used to transport goods from India and other countries to Sri Lanka through ships. Also, earlier time, there were a train service connected to ferry from India to here. You can see all these places if you go here.

Mannar is a sand island in the arid north of Sri Lanka. It was badly affected by the war and is only now starting to get back on its feet. It's a different experience to the rest of Sri Lanka and is worth a day or two side tour. You can arrive via bus or train. The journey across the causeway to the island is beautiful at high tide. There are donkeys throughout the island left by Arab traders. The donkeys are small but quite tame. They were the local taxi service for centuries but have been neglected with arrival of motorised vehicles. Bridging Lanka (48 New Moor st) are setting up a donkey education centre just outside town. They will shortly be running tours to try fund caring for these donkeys - contact them if you want to try set up a tour as we got to pat some beautiful well cared for donkeys in our visit. The baobab tree dates from the 1400s and is enormous. The local cathedral is nice. The Dutch fortress Is just at the end of the causeway on the island while it's small and was used during the war, you get great views from the walls.Just across the causeway on the Jaffna road is an ancient Hindu temple (Ketheeswaram) which is spectacular - and not a tourist in sight (remove shoes, men must remove their shirts and women must have shoulders and knees covered). Part of the temple is being restored and you can walk around the building site (!).  The Giants tank is a well known bird watching spot. Baobab guest house can provide tasty lunch for about $5 (if you want curry and rice they need a few hours notice but if you want egg and toast, shanthi can whip that up quickly) or the local ahash hotel was about the same cost. Mannar may not have the highlights of other parts of Sri Lanka but if you want to know what life is like for everyday Sri Lankans then this is a lovely stop over between Anuradhapura and Jaffna.
Hot dusty water problems unpleasant poor food choices really I wouldn't go out of my way to see this place

Sri lanka is an island and mannar is an Island that belongs to the main island. despite being an island it has no place to visit except the mannar fort which is very small and abandoned comparing to galle fort or trincomalee fort..
Rhe drive from mannar to thalai mannar is teally beautiful. Can see bird life there as well and saw several photograpgers with massive cameras taking pics of birds. Must visit if you re in mannar.

First the geography. Mannar and the associated tip  of the island,Talaimannar form the bottom claw of the Jaffna pincers extending into the sea. Mannar is slightly inland and Talaimannar is the tip. The two reasons why any visitor would want to visit this place are birds and history. The birds are quite exotic and plentiful in the area. The historical currency of this place is enhanced by the tale of Ramayana, an enduring epic in Sri Lanka and India. Talaimannar forms the Eastern edge of the fabled Adams bridge. On a good day and low tide, you can see the opposite end of these sand bars. That's all there is for the itinerant visitor. The drive from Mannar to Talaimannar is an hour an a half. The roads get progressively worse. Lot of military presence and a naval detachment right at the very tip of Talaimannar is a bit of a dampener. To reach the closest sandbars,called island 1 and 2, the help of local fishermen needs to be requisitioned. From the Indian side,Dhanushkodi,access to the sandbars is better. Reaching Mannar from central Lanka is on the A14. From the North,it is the A14. The roads are black tops for much of the way. Closing Mannar,the roads are not well lit and rough for long stretches. Advise against driving in the night. The arterial roads are patrolled by the police actively. Max speed is 70 kmph. In town limits are 40 to 50 kmph. The approach roads roads unlike much of Sri lanka are straight and don't wind. Food and overnight residence in Mannar are limited and average. It would help to carry food of choice and be prepared to stay in basic lodgings. An overnight stay with food should be no more than 60 usd per person. This is Mannar. Talaimannar has no amenities. Plan all trips by day. Avoid the rainy season. The local food is delicious but fiery. Breakdowns on the roads can ruin your timetable.Four wheel drives are best and a local guide recommended. Hospitality is unflaggingly super. Enjoy the trip !

An under developed area in the remote north western area of Sri Lanka it offers little or no 'tourist' attraction,  However to all those bird lovers out there - its a great place to be during the winter migration of birds.  The flamingos are the greatest attraction not forgetting many other species of migrant birds

Nice place to visit but extremely hot atmosphere. Four Tees inn is recommended for a family stay but make sure you get the new rooms at the back which have a very nice environment, with it's tiny petting zoo with rabbits and ducks. Visit the Pier to grab a ride to Adams Bridge
Excellent birding during the migrant season.  September to April. Especially  Flamingos , Waders and Ducks. A laid back beautiful part of Sri Lanka

There is nothing much to do or see here. The migratory bird sightings and habitats are on the mainland beyond the connecting causeway. The ferry and he train to Talaimanar do not operate anymore and there aren't any formal tours to the Adam's Bridge. There are a few lackluster beaches and Navy patrols many of them and do not allow bathing. Tuk tuks do not have meters and their fares are extremely high here. Hard to find regular brands of bottled water, alcohol or supermarket goods. It's a dry, hot laid back experience. You can see a few wild donkeys and birds
There is nothing of great interest here. I wasted a day coming here to visit. It's a backwater . Dont waste your time.

This is must visit place and the largest island of Sri Lanka. Mannar Island formerly called Manar Island, is part of Mannar District, Sri Lanka. It is linked to the main island of Sri Lanka by a causeway. It has an area of about 50 square kilometres, mainly covered with vegetation and sand. Ram setu is a chain of limestone shoals, between Pamban Island, also known as Rameswaram Island, off the southeastern coast of Tamil Nadu, India, and Mannar Island, off the northwestern coast of Sri Lanka. Geological evidence suggests that this bridge is a former land connection between India and Sri Lanka. We had a nice and wonderful time.

It was an amazing experience to all of us. The weather too very conducive for the most valuable boat trip to see the islands. Beautiful sceneries around.  A bit of advices are please take ample drinking water, some biscuits & sandwiches as less places to have meals but can manage. It was a one day trip for us and was really worthwhile
Mannar island can be treated as one of the best place to visit. This place can be treated as best place to see wetland birds and some of the ruins,
The weather is fair in the later and early parts of the year. Mid year is very hot and dry. October to early February is good for bird watching, since most of the migratory birds can bee see there

We visited Mannar on hearing that migratory flamingos had arrived there.  We were not disappointed and saw two large groups of flamingos numbering over 700 in each group.  They were a little too far for close up shots with my 400 mm lens.  I now feel sorry that we did not visit them early morning for better photographic shots!  If you move close they move away!! We also saw the big baobab tree with a girth of 19.5 m said to be planted by Arabian sailors around 1475. The Doric house was another historic attraction.  The then British governer of Ceylon, Sir Fredrick North, had occupied this building around 1800 to personally supervise the thriving and extremly lucrative pearl fishery in and around Mannar.  The building is in ruins and could be better managed by the authorities.  We also visited the light house and the Dutch Fort.  There are many other interesting places to be visited around Mannar as we spent most of our time looking at the Flamingos.  We certainly shall visit Mannar again to see the other interesting locations.

its about 120km from jaffna town.. we had a nice bike ride to mannar with friends.. there are some tourist places like thalai mannar adams bridge its around 30km straight road from mannar town.. we can see the bridge and beach and some fishing places... keeri beach also wonderful beach to take bath and a dutch fort and baobab tree and good food stalls to taste traditional food are there.. hot climate is irritating otherwise everything fine...

This is an amazing place. One of the drawbacks I noticed is not having many places to eat well. Other than that the beach is awesome, people seem nice as well. There are so many things around to watch. If you come by a vehicle I suggest you to go and visit the Kanchukulam Hanging Bridge.
Mannar is well known for it's birds. But there is more to see, like an old Dutch fort, the mansion of the English govenor and the famous Baobab trees which you will only find in Africa.
Mannar gives travellers a very different experience to the rest of the Island. You'll  see donkeys roam freely on the streets. Vast landscapes and a very diverse culture.

Mannar Island is accessible by both train, bus or car with excellent roadways for both modes of travel. It is a coastal town. #Hotel #Agape is one of the places which is very good. The #Portugese Fort, the #Baobab Tree, #Church of Our #LadyOf Madhu, Talai Mannar pier are must visits. Even the Northern capital Jaffna is accessible over an excellent short cut road within 2 hours.
Hot, windy and clear sky all round the island. This island combine to main island in a small bridge. Families living here doing fishing, one Naval base with Police station in there.

Not much to see or do, except some small sites. Nontheless Mannar is a nice place to visit. Definitly if you like to see wild ... donkeys!! They are all over town Things to do include seeing/visiting Adam's bridge, old and very big Bilbao tree in the centre and ....
Different climate than the other sides of Sri Lanka. Windy and hot.specialy the Adams bridge.some sandy islands with small plants.soo many birds were there. Unfortunately no flemingoes were seen.

This place is nice and different. I like mannar than Jaffna. The city is still developing so u will not find many things here. Saw a food city., sathosa, but the only reliable and good food place is choice reataurent. Located at Centre bazaar rd in the city.
Mannar island is a place where we could visit many places which are important historically. Moreover lots of fantastic senses are also available.

The town of Mannar is pretty scruffy with few amenities. It is a very mixed community that appear to live in harmony. There is a beach about 6 kms away and one at the end of the railway line, but they have quite a lot of rubbish. One would be a brave woman to swim in a swimsuit I was subject to a fair amount of sexual harassment and I'm 65! The newly constructed railway line is very pristine but I'm not certain if any trains actually traverse the length of the island. The old ferry pier which was used to link Sri Lanka with India is very dilapidated and the only talk now is of a bridge.

After the war great endeavours have been made to restore road and rail links that are both now excellent. The route into Mannar is long and straight and passes some stunning waterside landscapes - very similar to the journey into Jaffna. The main shopping area is the Grand Bazaar. Apart from the ruined Dutch Fort the only other building on a grand scale is the impressive cathedral/church (again similar in design to the one in Jaffna) We found that there was little choice of places to eat and there is an absence of any quality tourist accommodation at the current time

The drive into the island on the causeway was beautiful. The fort was not much but accorded a nice view of the surroundings. The island itself was charming, only place you could see wild donkeys. A good pit stop enroute Colombo to Jaffna though will not come here specifically for a visit as there's not much to see.

Mannar is one place in Sri Lanka where you can find a variety of exotic birds including the Flamingos. That seems to be the only reason one would ever go to Mannar. Ruff, Grebe, Open Bill painted woolly necked and adjutant storks, Pintail, Garganey, Spot billed duck, Teals gulls and terns Grey Francolin, Peafowl ..... The varieties are a lot.. Great place for birders to be

I visited and stayed here for a night as part of a Sri Lankan coastline cycle tour and then a year later as a self drive, it is a little conservative, and not touristy, many police and checkpoint controls. The new bridge leads into town, the old blown up bridge still visible to the right, there is a central town roundabout roads lead off, shops and a bustling market surround, impressive religious buildings to see, a fuel station and many banks with cashpoints and donkeys everywhere.

in wonderful weather we visited Mannar during 3 days. That was enough to explore and we loved the sight seeing, even after the floodings that took place 14 days before. Lots of birds to spot, friendly people. Unfortunately a great part of the road is in horrible condition but this Island has a real potential to be visited by tourists.

Mannar Island & the close by area of the main land possesses a very unique socio-cultural and geographic profile  in comparison to the other parts of Sri Lank. This is the largest Island belongs to Sri Lanka ( nearly 40 km in length and average 3 km in width. connected to the main land by a 3 km long road and a bridge at the entrance to the island. The sea which is on the both side of the road is just 2 feet deep in the high tide and becomes a massive dessert of white sand during law tide. Main attractions - Mannar Fort can be seen on your left when you enter the island. This was originally built by the Portuguese and further fortified by the Dutch and British and is still in a pretty good condition, and now are under preservation project of the Archaeological Department.  No tickets needed. There are few Dutch Tombs in the premises. - Adams Bridge at Thalei Mannar- Located around 35 km away from the Mannar town, Can be reached by Mannar - Thalai Mannar main road by Bus and Train. Public transportation goes only up to the Talai Mannar small town. The Adam's Bridge is the narrow belt of sand reefs and atolls runs from Thalai Mannar to Danushkodi at Pamban Island of India. Approximately 30 km in length  200 m in average width and 2 ft in average elevation , controlled by Sri Lanka Navy. During the day time between 7 am to 4 pm visitors can go there on private boats that can be arranged talking to any of the fishermen living there. In October 2015 it was 2500 rupees for a pack of 6 people for a 2 hrs visit. The boater should provide slandered life jackets to all the passengers and passengers must be wearing it all the time they are on board. if not sometimes the Navy even will send you all the way back to the shore cancelling your trip. after 4 pm you can not stay there under any circumstances. hope this will change in the near future to a level that you can camp in the night with special permission. Extremely warm and dry, better keep hydrating yourself through out the journey. - Fort Arippu - A small fort located on the road to Puththalama via Silavathurai. You can see the ruins of a small fortification originally done by the Portuguese and occupied by the Dutch and the British latter. - Doric Mansion - Located on the shore on the same road passing the Fort Arippu. One of the mansions of the 1st British Governor of Sri Lanka (then Ceylon). The mansion is in ruin but still you can see the great brick walls and arches. Kudhiramale Cliffs point in the shore of Vipattu forest, Thiruketheeshvaram Hindhu Temple, The Giant Tank, The Catholic Shrine of Madu, St. Lucia church, Baiobab trees, Sandy jungle beaches and couple of sanctuaries are located in the Mannar island and the adjoining main land. I first visited Mannar in 2010 and have gone there more than 20 times. Nothing much in terms of entertainment. but if you are interested in just observing a unique social set up, some of the oldest catholic customs in the south Asia, and colonial History, Mannar is awesome.  Not very developed in comparison to the other parts of the  country. Around 20 Hotels are found in the area. one of the hottest and driest climate in the country.

A quiet place by the sea full of wonderful people. Go to experience authentic village life. Stay a while and volunteer at an NGO. Help look after the Bridging Lanka donkeys. Visit the sites but stay and meet the people you won't be disappointed. The town is full of wildlife and domestic animals. The bird life here and in the Mannar Province is abundant. Visit Keeri Beach and help clean it up for the future. Take long bicycle rides around the town and the villages.  Take a three wheeler to the mainland and visit the sacred Hindu lake and temple. You can now catch a train directly to Mannar from Colombo or anywhere along the line. Its great to visit in July and August because the winds are up and it cools you down.  The mornings and evening are very pleasant and the breezes are wonderful.

We stayed at Palmyrah house which is on the Island.  The island is quite hot and dry with lots of donkeys.  You can visit the Talaimannar pier from here.  Fun fact: From the pier it is closer to travel to India than to Mannar town!!

Visited with family and its a nice place to visit. mannar fort , Bio bab tree ,lagoon , Iron / steel light house in Urumalei, beach and shopping in Mannar town are interesting. Brought good dry fish and they are reasonably cheap. Do not forget to see the sand banks of Adams bridge. carry extra water bottles, a good binocular , shades and caps. Area is dry and hot . Cotton/ linen  is the most  suitable attire. There are lot of things to preserve in Mannar ford and its a very interesting place.

We never feel that we have such a beautiful landscape in this country until we go out for a holiday. Mannar is a separate island connected by a beautiful causeway to the mainland. It is a fishing island, covered with palmyrah trees on typical white sand. People are back to their normal life after ending the war but war damaged buildings can be seen here and there. The life of people are very simple, genuine and they are not that corrupted like in the city people in many other parts. I was amazing to see the selling price of dried fish as Rs. 200.00 /kg ($1.5/kg). We were unable to watch birds as it was not the birds season. Finding a good restaurant is the most difficult and some people speak only Tamil.

The causeway connecting the island with the mainland is once again passable. This is the ideal time to watch Flamingoes in Mannar. Thousands of birds could be watched in the salterns. Wild Donkeys are straying all over.

I am not sure whether it is closer to India that Mannar Island has a very close similarity to South Indian villages. Avoid going during the warm seasons (April - June) as the climate is naturally hot. On the way you travel, expect herds of cows alongside the main road. Mannar is one of the only places where you can spectate donkeys aside the road. Go to the seashore and have a conversation with the local fishermen. They have interesting stories to share.
I do hope they protect the island and educate the locals about how precious their land is for all the resident and migrant birds.

An island, connected with manmade road/bridge over the ocean/laggon. Developing gradually and becoming a attractive place. Famous adams bridge connects from here i.e Talai Mannar. Some good beaches around - and mostly low laying areas. You may find difficult to get a good food though unless pre-organized. Though fried rice/curry commonly available.
but a must see! we travel all over the other parts of the world without seeing our own Island , so much to appreciate.

We stayed at Palmyrah House which was a nice place with great meals & a pool. Mannar is a very different side of Sri Lanka than we have seen so far. It's a very poor area recovering from the conflict. It's also a dry zone so fewer trees and no hills here. Very few tourists here. Local people friendly & many speak English. The bird life here is amazing as well saw cows, goats, donkeys, frogs, huge fish, wild horses and of course dogs!

It was a very lovely experience at mannar. The island has a beautiful environment although it's hot and has few attractions such as the longest brigde in SL, Dutch fort and the tree which has the biggest trunk (Baobab). But the road in Mannar town is horrible. People are very nice.

Practically all of the time I was the solely foreigner around - a strange sort of sensation, with people calling and waiving from all directions, smiling and striking out casual conversations. Some people here call the area a dump, still for me it was a valuable insight in the region recovering from the war. It is the people whom I found most surprising - extremely opened and friendly for a region with a recent history like that.

Its definitely a place with its own beauty and scenarios and offers a unique experience. If you are the total explorer open to new experiences and ready to taste the true flavors of the places you visit its indeed a pleasurable trip. But if you are fussy about food and accommodation Mannar may not really be your place. You do not have much choice of food restaurants or accommodation but the food definitely has a flavor of its own. Its probably the only city where you get Goats, Donkeys, Cattle and Humans living in harmony. The donkeys are adorable and harmless. If you are looking to get away from your city life and wanting a break with a totally different experience its your place for sure

Except the old Fort lots of birds and the funny Baobab tree (looks like wider than tall)in town and mangy wild donkeys there is absolutely nothing of interest here! Beaches could be nice but you can see and feel the closeness to India because all of tthem look like a plastic dump - absolutely horrible!
mannar island is totally amazing. The best time to go is during december as the weather is good. Good for bird watching

There is little on the island itself that would interest the casual tourist. However, if you know any local folks, then Mannar is a wonderful relaxing place to visit. Interestingly, the place is loaded with donkeys, which were introduced by the Portuguese. But this in itself isn't enough to make a special trip. Mannar town itself is a sleepy little place, and there isn't anything of interest for the casual tourist. If you are going to visit the shrine at Madhu, then I would suggest spending the night in Mannar; it's fairly close, and has the best accommodations in the District. I would also suggest one night in Mannar if you are driving the coastal road to Jaffna in order to break the trip up.

Mannar is a beautiful place. There aren’t many places in Sri Lanka that you get to see donkeys freely roaming around like cattle in the rest of the island.  Perfect place to spot birds. We stopped at the bird sanctuary just at the entrance to the island and spotted variety of birds.  In season, I am sure Mannar must be a bird watches paradise. The place is rapidly changing after many years of civil conflict. The blown up bridge alongside the new bridge is reminder of the dark history of the island. The place is now very safe and the people are very helpful. The beaches are beautiful and plenty of shells that are not commonly found elsewhere. The place has basic facilities but there are no super markets. Recommend carrying adequate water and a full tank of fuel. Power shortages are common so recommend carrying a torch and staying in a hotel with a generator.

I visited this place after 40 years, lots of changes. This island is connected by road with the main island, there is enough transport to Colombo and other major cities, I saw the railway road is under construction and I am told it will be completed within few months. (most parts of the road is completed) This city (island is famous among Hindus and Catholic because of Madhu St. Marys chursh and Thiruketheeswaram (a very ancient popular Sivan Temple). both are not in the city but little away with good public transport connection. In the city there is a huge tree which you MUST see this is the largest tree in Asia (huge trunk). Aprt from this you can go to Thalai Mannar pier which is about 45 minutes drive this is a historical place which was the landing port from (South India) Rameswaram. Old train road and the pier still there.(Please check with Navy who is in the town whether you can visit because some days it is closed by them) Mannar is getting busy these days, another city in SriLanka. You do see lots of wild Donkeys in this area be careful, they can kick and harm you (not always but there are several incidents) It is fun to watch them, some times they stand still all of a sudden they run or scream, real fun. There are few places to stay Sorry, I did not stay there so no comment. In short it is a dry but charming place.

This is one of the best cities I have ever visited in Sri Lanka. However accommodation options were less, unless you're fine with guesthouses. There're so many things to see in this lovely city. We set out from Colombo & took a short cut via the Oyamaduwa road which bypassed Medawachchiya & saved us about 45 minutes drive time. First we visited the Kunchikulam Suspension Bridge en route to Mannar. This was one of the hidden gems which is still standing strong. However the road leading upto the bridge was a bit damaged. Afterwards we proceeded to Thiruketishwaram Kovil & Madhu Church. Both very beautiful sites. Spent the night in a nice clean guesthouse which was well worth the money we paid. The next day morning we visited Talaimannar & took a boat trip to Adam's Bridge. This is another breathtaking experience. The Sri Lankan Navy operates this & if the Ocean is rough, they will not operate. Luckily it was a good day. In the afternoon we visited Arippu Fort which was a Dutch built Fort to which Robert Knox fled while escaping from the Kandyan King during ancient times. Close to the fort is the Dorric House which was the bungalow of the 1st British Governor of Sri Lanka - Fredrick North. Better hurry since this site is at the edge of a cliff & parts of it is being washed to the Ocean. After several years, the entire site will be gone. The road to Arripu from Mannar was a bit bumpy. Spent the night at our cozy guesthouse. Next day morning visited the Vankalai Bird Sanctuary which was a major success for us. I'm not that much into birds, but still I enjoyed seeing so many different birds at that time of the day. In the afternoon we visited the Mannar fort & proceeded back to Colombo.

I have never heard of Mannar being mentioned as a travel option among my friends, but I will recommend it in future as a must visit. The two famed places of worship on the A14, the beautiful island of Mannar and its beaches and the amazing Adam's bridge, add the Palmyrah House to that - great!

Mannar Island is in the north west of Sri Lanka, a six to seven hour drive from Colombo on good roads. A new road and railway  line are under construction and could reduce the travelling time -- but six/ seven hours , with a couple of rest stops , was not a problem and we arrived at our destination in great shape. Our group of nine spent two days here, relaxing and exploring. Mannar has much to offer -- it is off the beaten track so there are no crowds and this is a great plus point ( let's hope it stays that way ). Great beaches, bird watching during the winter bird migration, sea food, gorgeous sunsets , a boat trip to the Adam's Bridge causeway are a few of the things you could do here. Madhu Church ( one of Sri Lanka's most important Catholic pilgrimage sites ) is just half an hour away. Accommodation is limited at the moment -- but there are some surprisingly good options.  We stayed at The Palmyrah House, which is a perfect little five bedroom boutique hotel. We loved it and plan to return soon.

We visited Mannar over the weekend and it is a paradise for bird watchers. We saw migrant birds  Greater Flamingos more than 1000, black tail godwits, Gargneys, Pintail ducks, Gulls, Plovers, terns all in flocks of several hundreds. So many raptors, white bellied sea eagles, brahamin kites, black kites, common kestrels and one booted eagle seen. In addition crab plovers more than 100 and pied avocet around 50 were spotted. For one day we have seen more than 1000 birds. It was really a paradise for bird watchers.
